results.display_title: Accidental Courtesy: Daryl Davis, Race & America
results.headline: Review: ‘Accidental Courtesy’ Is Gentle Persuasion for Bigots
results.summary_short: A man who confronts racism with friendliness in his travels.

results.headline: Review: ‘Between Us’ Sends a Couple Into a Sudden Tailspin
results.summary_short: Rafael Palacio Illingworth’s film stars Olivia Thirlby and Ben Feldman as a couple whose search for a new place to live opens an unexpected rift.

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Ardennes,’ a Freed Convict Returns Home to a New Reality
results.summary_short: Robin Pront’s film depicts a man who took the fall for a crime and who catches up with his brother and his girlfriend, now reformed and in a relationship, four years later.

results.headline: Revisiting Concentration Camp Atrocities in Shattering Clarity
results.summary_short: “German Concentration Camps Factual Survey,” completed and restored, is a ghastly, essential record of the liberation of Bergen-Belsen and others.

results.headline: Review: ‘Arsenal’ Finds Nicolas Cage as a Criminal, Not Playing Nice
results.summary_short: This movie, directed by Steven C. Miller, follows two brothers under pressure by a crime boss in Mississippi.

results.headline: Review: In ‘A Different American Dream,’ a Portrait of Resignation
results.summary_short: In giving a voice to people dismayed by the disruption caused by oil drilling in North Dakota, “A Different American Dream” captures a melancholy defeatism.

results.headline: Review: It’s Slick, but ‘Master’ Is No James Bond Movie
results.summary_short: The bloat of this routine South Korean crime thriller, directed by Cho Ui-seok, magnifies its generic qualities.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Master

results.headline: Review: ‘Railroad Tigers’ Features a Resourceful Jackie Chan
results.summary_short: Mr. Chan, 62, dazzles in this action movie set during the Second Sino-Japanese War, but the most challenging moves are left to younger stuntmen.

results.headline: Review: ‘Dr. Feelgood: Dealer or Healer?’ It’s Not a Simple Question
results.summary_short: This film’s director, Eve Marson, looks at the ethics of prescribing pain medication and at Dr. William Hurwitz, who was prosecuted for narcotics distribution.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dr. Feelgood: Dealer or Healer?

results.headline: Review: In Jim Jarmusch’s ‘Paterson,’ a Meditative Flow of Words Into Poetry
results.summary_short: This story of a soulful bus driver and basement poet is deceptively simple and nearly perfect, with a likely nod to William Carlos Williams.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paterson

results.headline: Review: 1 Teenage Boy and 3 Mothers in ‘20th Century Women’
results.summary_short: Annette Bening stars as a complicated and divorced Santa Barbara mother in Mike Mills’s funny, emotionally piercing new film.

results.headline: Review: ‘Ocean Waves,’ a Tale of Young Love, Ghibli Style
results.summary_short: In a 1993 gem from this revered Japanese animation studio, high school boys in a small island city encounter a girl from Tokyo.

results.headline: Review: ‘I, Daniel Blake,’ Stuck on the Bureaucratic Hamster Wheel
results.summary_short: In this film by Ken Loach, a working-class man in Britain is caught between the medical and employment bureaucracies.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Toni Erdmann,’ Dad’s a Prankster Trying to Jolt His Conformist Daughter
results.summary_short: The funniest almost-three-hour German comedy you will ever see, Maren Ade’s film is a thrilling act of defiance against the toxicity of doing what is expected.

results.headline: Review: A Father’s Dreams, Recast by His Daughters in ‘Dangal’
results.summary_short: This Bollywood film about a father who trains his two daughters to be wrestlers sets emotions to full blast and wears it heart firmly on its sleeve.

results.headline: Review: He Pledges Allegiance Only to His Tommy Gun, in ‘Live by Night’
results.summary_short: Ben Affleck directed and stars in this gangster movie set in the 1920s, in which he tries to pour new wine into a bullet-riddled vessel.

results.headline: Review: Questions and Prayers Go Unanswered in Scorsese’s ‘Silence’
results.summary_short: In Martin Scorsese’s film, Jesuit priests in 17th-century Japan operate underground to keep their religion alive when they and their adherents are persecuted.

results.headline: Review: ‘Hidden Figures’ Honors 3 Black Women Who Helped NASA Soar
results.summary_short: The women, part of the giant step for mankind, have their stories told in this movie directed by Theodore Melfi.

results.headline: Review: ‘Why Him?’ Better Yet, Why This Movie?
results.summary_short: Proving definitively that slapping James Franco’s scenery-eating grin on any old drivel doesn’t guarantee entertainment, this film is trite, crass and moronic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Why Him?

results.headline: Review: ‘A Monster Calls,’ Offering a Boy a Lifeline
results.summary_short: Liam Neeson is the voice of a giant tree that helps a child with a vivid imagination through difficult times.
